I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  While each country is unique, the Pacific small island developing states (SIDS)1 are 
among the most vulnerable in the world to natural hazards, climate change, and economic 
volatility and shocks. This regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support 
the Pacific SIDS in building awareness of the challenges they face; and review global experience 
to consider innovative options to work with partners, including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
to assist them in building resilience to economic, disaster, and climate-related shocks and 
stresses.  
 
2.  The  TA  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030, 2  which  recognizes  the  distinct 
development challenges facing SIDS, many of which are fragile and conflict-affected situations 
(FCAS),3 and outlines ADB’s differentiated approach to these groups of developing member 
countries (DMCs). The TA is in line with the priorities of ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2016–2020;4 
Climate Change Operational Framework, 2017–2030;5 and the Pacific Regional Operations 
Business Plan, 2019–2021.6 ADB approved the TA’s concept paper on 13 December 2018, with 
a budget of $450,000 from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6).   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB’s Pacific DMCs are some of the smallest and most remote countries in the world and 
are on the front line in responding to climate change. Dispersion and distance to markets limit 
economies of scope and scale, resulting in “speed limits”  to growth. Narrowly based economies 
and often high reliance on imports mean that the economic growth is volatile, with SIDS among 
the most-affected countries from global economic shocks. Infrastructure and service delivery 
costs are very high. SIDS are extremely vulnerable to natural hazards—a situation exacerbated 
by climate change. Pacific women and girls are especially vulnerable, with wide-ranging gender 
inequalities in access to employment and wage gaps, education outcomes, health outcomes, and 
gender-based violence both contributing to and exacerbated by economic shocks, disasters, and 
climate risks. 
 
4.  ADB’s Charter gives special attention to the needs of smaller and less-developed member 
countries.7 This is reinforced in Strategy 2030’s recognition of the need for a differentiated 
approach to addressing SIDS’ extreme vulnerability and to assist them in meeting the Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG5 on gender equality, to which ADB is committed. 
ADB’s active portfolio of investments in the Pacific SIDS has grown from less than $500 million in 
2005 to almost $2.7 billion at the end of 2017. Many of the smaller SIDS receive exceptional 
access to concessional resources and will especially benefit from the ADB Board’s decision in 
November 2018 to increase minimum concessional allocations for all countries to $13 million per 
                                                
1  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) follows the United Nations definition of SIDS, which defines SIDS as all states 
that participate in the Alliance of Small Island States. All 14 Pacific ADB developing member countries (DMCs) are 
consequently classified SIDS.  
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  Seven of the nine DMCs currently classified by ADB as FCAS are Pacific SIDS: the Federated States of Micronesia, 
Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, and Tuvalu. Even SIDS not classified as 
FCAS face severe capacity limitations and exhibit characteristics of structural fragility. 
4  ADB. 2017. Pacific Approach, 2016–2020. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2017. Climate Change Operational Framework 2017–2030: Enhanced Actions for Low Greenhouse Gas 
Emissions and Climate-Resilient Development. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2018. Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan, 2019–2021. Manila. 
7   ADB. 1966.  Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank.  Manila (Article 2ii).

2 
annum for 2019 and 2020. ADB has expanded its staff presence and will have staff in every 
current Pacific DMC by 2020. Innovation marked ADB engagement in the Pacific SIDS. This 
includes, among other things, joint cofinancing of investments with partners, successful efforts to 
mobilize more than $136 million in Green Climate Fund resources,8 the use of flexible instruments 
to provide rapid financing following disasters,9 and the development of potential new guarantee 
instruments to mobilize greater private investment. Despite the daunting challenges facing the 
Pacific SIDS, ADB investments have achieved significant results,10 and helped countries improve 
development  outcomes,  even  if  progress  has not  been  sufficient for all  countries  to  meet 
ambitious Millennium Development Goal targets.11 
 
5.  The Pacific SIDS are keen to work closely with partners, including ADB, to ensure that 
international support is sustained and continues to evolve to assist SIDS in overcoming unique 
challenges and meeting their own development priorities. Continued innovation will be critical if 
ADB is to maintain its historical leadership role when a wide range of partners are increasing 
support for the Pacific SIDS. This will require a broad consensus among shareholders on strategic 
priorities. ADB’s SIDS DMCs look forward to the ADB Annual Meeting in Fiji in May 2019—the 
first by any multilateral development bank in a Pacific DMC—as an opportunity to highlight the 
unique vulnerabilities of SIDS, as well as development successes. ADB SIDS DMCs are hoping 
that the Annual Meeting will provide a basis for ADB shareholders to consider further policy 
changes,  as  part  of  the  Asian  Development  Fund  13  replenishment  process,  to  apply  a 
differentiated approach to SIDS. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
6.  The TA will support the Pacific SIDS to (i) highlight to key development partners the 
extreme vulnerability of Pacific SIDS to climate change, natural hazards, and economic volatility, 
as well as SIDS’ own successful efforts, with ADB support, to build resilience to shocks and 
stresses; (ii) undertake research to consider and suggest further policy and program changes by 
partners, including ADB, to engage innovatively to meet their needs; and (iii) consider options, 
based on global experience, to mobilize greater sovereign and nonsovereign financing to build 
climate change and disaster resilience. The TA will complement and build on other analytical work 
by ADB, including the Pacific Economic Monitor, which has undertaken policy analysis of issues 
contributing to Pacific vulnerability; Pacific regional TA projects strengthening climate and disaster 
resilience of investments,12 considering new business processes to design, implement, and 
maintain investments in fragile situations;13 institutional analysis on the interlinkages between 
gender, climate change, and disaster risk in Asia and the Pacific and priorities to strengthen 
                                                
8  Green Climate Fund. Funding Proposal 8 Fiji urban water supply and wastewater management (November 2015), 
Funding Proposal 36 Pacific Islands renewable energy investment program (October 2016), Funding Proposal 52 
Nauru sustainable and climate resilient connectivity (October 2017), Funding Proposal 90 Tonga renewable energy 
(October 2018), and Funding Proposal 91 South Tarawa water supply project (October 2018). 
9  ADB. Cook Islands: Disaster Resilience Program; ADB. Regional: Pacific Disaster Resilience Program; and ADB. 
Palau Disaster Resilience Program. 
10 Between 2010 and 2018, ADB has financed (i) more than 1,000 kilometers of roads across the region, improving 
access to services for more than 2 million people; (ii) broadband information and communication technology cables 
in Tonga, Samoa, and Palau, improving connectivity and reducing costs; (iii) 126 megawatts of new electricity 
generation—about 10% of total installed capacity in the region; and (iv) improved water supply for 400,000 
households and sanitation for 150,000 households.   
11 Since ADB’s establishment in 1966, the average life expectancy in Pacific SIDS, including for women, has increased 
from less than 60 in 1966 to more than 70; infant mortality has declined by two-thirds; and primary school enrollments 
have increased from 69% in 1990 to 95% in 2018, with girls outnumbering boys at school in a range of countries. 
12 ADB. Regional: Strengthening Climate and Disaster Resilience of Investments in the Pacific. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2018. Regional: Towards Effective and Sustainable Delivery of Development Results in Fragile Situations in 
the Pacific; ADB. Regional: Implementing a Differentiated Approach to Urban Development in the Pacific.  Manila.

3 
women’s  resilience;14 Pacific  regional  TA  on  gender  equality;15 and  institutional  TA  being 
undertaken by the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department on climate change 
issues and oceans. The TA team will work closely with other bilateral and multilateral development 
partners to learn from their experience, both globally and in the Pacific, and where possible, 
identify common solutions.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: increased resilience of Pacific SIDS to shocks 
and stresses resulting from economic volatility, natural hazards, and climate change. The TA will 
have the following outcome: strengthened SIDS capacity to undertake reforms and to engage 
with development partners, including ADB, to advocate for sustained engagement and identify 
innovative solutions to build resilience to economic vulnerability and extreme exposure to natural 
hazard and climate change risks.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Gender-sensitive analysis of the vulnerability of the Pacific small island 
developing states conducted and successful lessons in building resilience shared. The TA 
will finance research on the particular vulnerabilities of SIDS, including an analysis of SIDS’ 
economic constraints and volatility as well as exposure and vulnerability to natural hazards and 
the high and rising financing needs to build climate change and disaster resilience. The TA will 
also finance research to explore lessons from successful efforts by SIDS, both in the Pacific and 
globally, to build resilience and make progress towards SDGs, including SDG5 on gender equality, 
and the importance of sustained international support to do so. Initial research findings will be 
disseminated in the lead-up to the ADB Annual Meeting in Fiji in May 2019. This will include 
seminar discussions with ADB shareholders, stakeholders from DMCs including gender ministries, 
regional organizations, bilateral and multilateral development partners, women’s organizations 
and other civil society groups, and as appropriate through the media.   
 
9.  Output 2: Lessons from policy reforms by ADB and other partners in taking a 
differentiated approach to small island developing states identified and shared. Initial 
research in 2019 will consider the evolving approach of other multilateral partners in the terms, 
volume, and flexible instruments that are being extended to assist SIDS in making progress 
toward achieving the SDGs, building resilience to economic shocks, and responding effectively 
to climate change and disaster risks. The research team will review, among others, the World 
Bank’s evolving approach to small states, including the establishment of a clear framework for 
exceptional eligibility to concessional resources with clear entry and exit criteria; and the status 
of  work  by  the  World  Bank,  United  Nations,  and  Commonwealth  Secretariat  to  develop 
vulnerability indices, including any gendered vulnerability measures. Analysis will include an 
assessment of the effectiveness of growing financial flows from a wide range of partners, including 
ADB, to the Pacific SIDS (including options to strengthen the capacity of the Pacific DMCs to 
absorb increased funding given significant financing needs to enhance resilience). 
 
10.  Output 3: Gender-sensitive research on innovative global approaches to climate 
action, building disaster resilience, and improving environmental management of oceans 
                                                
14 ADB. Regional: Strengthening Women’s Resilience to Climate Change and Disaster Risk in Asia and the Pacific; 
ADB, United Nations Women. 2018. Gender Equality and the Sustainable Development Goals in Asia and the Pacific: 
Baseline and pathways for transformative change by 2030. Manila. This report provides more data (and points to the 
data gaps in the Pacific) and evidence on interlinkages between climate change and gender equality.   
15 ADB. Regional: Promoting Evidence-Based Policy Making for Gender Equity in the Pacific (Phase 2).

4 
conducted and shared. Research will consider ways SIDS are globally mobilizing resources—
both sovereign and nonsovereign—to build resilience to climate change and disasters, including 
proposals from the secretariat to Fiji’s 23rd Conference of the Parties to the United Nations 
Framework Convention on Climate Change presidency and Pacific regional organizations. This 
could include specific analysis of (i) options to mobilize greater private financing for climate 
change mitigation (such as by encouraging investments in renewable energy generation), and 
climate adaptation and disaster resilience (such as by encouraging extended access to disaster 
insurance for households and businesses); (ii) the potential scope to support SIDS to mobilize 
private financing for resilience objectives, such as through green bonds, catastrophe bonds, or 
gender bonds; and (iii) the global experience of SIDS and others in mobilizing financing for 
conservation efforts, such as debt-for-nature swaps and financing for SIDS’ efforts to improve 
marine protection. Research will consider options to support efforts both globally and by the 
Pacific SIDS to address the common challenge of safeguarding healthy oceans. Analysis will 
include the gender impacts of different options. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2.   
 
12.  The  governments  of  participating  DMCs  will  make  relevant  country  data  available, 
nominate participants to join capacity-building activities and meetings related to this TA, and 
provide other in-kind contributions. As regional TA focused primarily on undertaking research and 
disseminating analytical outcomes, ADB will not require significant inputs from the Pacific DMCs. 
ADB will seek no objections from the relevant governments before any activities in a specific 
country instead of a no objection from all the Pacific governments before starting the TA. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. The Pacific Department will administer and 
implement the TA over 24 months, from 1 January 2019 to 31 December 2020, in close 
coordination with the Pacific Department resident missions and other relevant departments 
including the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. 
 
14.  Knowledge and research findings funded by the TA will be disseminated through various 
platforms. This will include the preparation of analytical reports and brochures, awareness-raising 
seminars and workshops, and potentially a flagship event on options to build resilience to climate 
and disaster risks and the economic vulnerability of SIDS in the Pacific. ADB will make all outputs 
freely available to the public through its corporate website and will produce limited copies for 
general dissemination and targeted workshops in the ADB headquarters, representative offices, 
and resident missions.

16.  Consulting services. The TA will finance international and national consulting services.16 
The TA will require an estimated 30 person-months of consultant services, including about 6 
person-months for component 1 and 24 person-months for components 2 and 3. Consultant 
inputs will be required to conduct research and assessments, draft publicity material, and prepare 
and deliver workshops. The consultants will consist of economists and public policy specialists, 
climate change and disaster risk reduction specialists, gender specialists, and other sectoral 
expertise as required.  ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time), its associated staff instructions and/or project administration 
instructions. ADB will recruit the consultants for required for output 1 either directly as individual 
consultants, or through a firm, through single source selection, as provided for in the staff 
instructions for ADB Administered Consulting Services for very small assignments which do not 
exceed $100,000. ADB will recruit the consultants required for outputs 2 and 3 either directly as 
individual consultants, or through a firm, in which case ADB will select the firm using quality- and 
cost-based  selection.  Disbursements  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). ADB will require the 
consultants to submit quarterly progress reports and final reports to ADB. ADB will evaluate their 
performance based on the findings of assessments by ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis for 
Building Resilience in the Pacific Small Island Developing States, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.
